newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Singapore HSFO seen steady to soft on supplies.
newsitem.headline: Singapore HSFO seen steady to soft on supplies.

text.p: High sulphur fuel oil prices on Tuesday were assessed steady to lower, traders said.
They said the crude market is neutral, registering just a marginal drop in prices. But cash fundamentals remained weak, traders said.
"There are still a lot of supplies in the region," said a western trader.
Traders said they are watching Chinese fuel oil demand. Chinese buyers were enquiring for cargoes but most were not firm on their purchase, they said.
Chinese buyers were asking at $7.50 per tonne over Singapore spot quotes c-and-f southern China.
But bunker demand were healthy, traders said. "This would limit the fall in prices," said a Japanese trader.
India has issued a term tender to buy 180,000 tonnes of fuel oil for delivery between December 1996 and January 1997. India has also tendered to sell heavy residual fuel oil in December.
Taiwan has issued a tender to sell high sulphur fuel oil in December.
In the swaps market, fuel oil was quoted firmer for balance November traded earlier at $119.50.
Balance November was quoted at $119.25/$120.00, December was seen at $118.25/$119.00 and January at $117.00/$118.00 a tonne, all up about $1.00 from Friday's levels.
The swaps market was close on Monday for the Deepavali holiday.
